clinical_study.brief_title: Balance Recovery Training for Fall Prevention in Retirement Communities
clinical_study.official_title: Balance Recovery Training for Fall Prevention in Retirement Communities

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this translational research study is to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of balance recovery training as an on-site fall prevention exercise intervention for older adults living in retirement communities. Falls are the leading cause of injuries and injury-related deaths among older adults over the age of 65 in the United States. While it is generally accepted that exercise helps prevent falls, exercise does not always reduce the number of falls, and it remains unclear which types of exercise are most effective at preventing falls. Balance recovery training (BRT) is a novel exercise intervention that has that has the potential to decrease the number of falls among older adults by improving their balance recovery ability after common balance perturbations such as tripping. BRT involves repeatedly exposing individuals to postural perturbations in a safe, controlled setting that allows reactive balance recovery to be practiced and improved. The investigators will administer BRT on-site at continuing care retirement communities over four weeks to older adult fallers and determine its effects on balance recovery ability over the following six months compared to another group of older adult fallers performing Tai Chi as an alternative exercise intervention. To further address the potential for BRT to be translated into typical practice within retirement communities, the investigators will also collect data on facilitators and barriers to the long-term sustainability of BRT in retirement communities using qualitative methods. These quantitative (balance recovery ability) and qualitative (implementation process) measures will provide the basis for a subsequent large practical clinical trial to test the effectiveness of BRT on reducing the number of falls among older adults.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in balance recovery ability from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: Balance recovery ability will be the the maximum torso angle during a simulated trip, and be measures in degrees. Larger angles indicate worse performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in timed-up-and-go test from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: The timed-up-and-go tests is measured in seconds. Longer times indicate worse performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in unipedal stance time from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: The unipedal stance time is measured in seconds, up to a maximum of 30 seconds. Longer times indicate better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximum step length from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: Maximum step length is measured in centimeters. Longer maximum step length indicates better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in activities-specific balance confidence (ABC) scale from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: ABC confidence scale ranges from 0% to 100%. Larger values indicate more confidence.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: POMA ranges from 0 to 28. Larger values indicate better mobility.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention
primary_outcome.description: The Berg balance test ranges from 0 to 56. Larger values indicate better balance.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of falls during everyday life
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 months after completing four weeks of exercise intervention

clinical_study.condition: Accidental Falls, Aged, Exercise Movement Techniques

arm_group.description: Participants will perform 30-minute Tai Chi sessions (Yang Short form) 3 times a week for 4 weeks.
Participants will practice balance recovery on a modified treadmill for approximately 30-minutes per session, 3 sessions a week for 4 weeks.

intervention.description: Participants will practice recovering their balance after a perturbation similar to tripping while walking. Each of these 'balance recovery training' sessions will last approximately 30 minutes, and will be performed 3 times per week for 4 weeks.
Participants will perform Tai Chi exercises (Yang short form) for 30 minutes, 3 times a week for 4 weeks. Each session will be led by an experienced Tai Chi instructor.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Must have either 1) fallen and hurt themselves in the past year, 2) fallen two or more times in the past year, or 3) be afraid that they might fall because of balance or walking problems?
- Must not have a fragility fracture in the past 10 years
- Must be age 60 or older
- Must be a resident of local continuing care retirement community (CCRC)
- Must not require assistance in performing normal daily activities
- Must be able to walk down a long hallway without any aids (cane, walker, etc.)
- Must not smoke
- Must not be in physical therapy
- Must not perform more than 150 minutes/week of moderate to vigorous aerobic activity
- Must score 24 or higher on Folstein Mini Mental Status Exam
- Must have less than 20% probability of major osteoporotic fracture as assessed by the fracture risk assessment tool (FRAX) score
